author: Jeff Poor
description: Gowdy: No Reauthorization of Surveillance Programs Until Unmasking Questions Answered
title: Gowdy: No Reauthorization of Surveillance Programs Until Unmasking Questions Answered - Breitbart

description: By a 3-0 vote, the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Virginia said the Wikimedia Foundation, which hosts the Wikipedia online encyclopedia, can pursue a challenge to the government's "Upstream" surveillance program.  The decision could make it easier for people to learn whether
title: Wikipedia can pursue NSA surveillance lawsuit: U.S. appeals court

author: David Kravets
description: “This surveillance will finally face badly needed scrutiny in our public courts.”
title: Wikimedia wins small victory in challenge to NSA “Upstream” spying

author: Bob Van Voris
description: Fox News struck back at former host Andrea Tantaros and her lawyer, telling a judge her claims the network carried out a campaign of harassment, intimidation and electronic surveillance is “an outright hoax.”
title: Fox News Calls Ex-Host's ‘Sockpuppet’ Harassment Claims a Hoax

author: Barbara Starr and Zachary Cohen, CNN
description: Two Chinese J-10 fighter jets conducted unsafe maneuvers while intercepting a US surveillance aircraft that was operating in international airspace near the South China Sea, according to the Navy.
title: Chinese jets conduct unsafe maneuver near US aircraft

author: Jeremy Page
description: The Pentagon said two Chinese jet fighters unsafely intercepted a U.S. naval surveillance plane over the South China Sea in the second such incident around China’s shores in a week.
title: Chinese Jets Intercept U.S. Navy Plane, Pentagon Says

author: ABC News
description:
Two Chinese J-10 fighter jets came within several hundred feet of a U.S. Navy P-3 Orion over the South China Sea on Thursday local time, U.S. officials said.
The fighters flew 200 yards in front of the P-3 maritime surveillance aircraft with an altitude separation of 100 feet, an encounter the...
title: Chinese jets come within several hundred feet of US plane over South China Sea

author: LORNE COOK
description: BRUSSELS (AP) — It sounds strange to characterize the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as a huge gun club, but the comparison can be useful in understanding the world's biggest military alliance. Like many gun clubs, NATO actually has no weapons of its own. The battleships, war planes, missiles and potential pool of more than 3 million personnel are owned and brought to the range by the 28 member states, mostly at their own cost. The only military equipment NATO has is a fleet of early warning radar planes and, from next year, five surveillance drones.
title: NATO, the world's biggest military alliance, explained
